There has been lately completed and placed
in position at Homewood, the first Class
Memorial to be erected there. It is a handsome
sun-dial, built by the Class of 1908, and placed
at the West end of the Botanical Gardens.
The plans for the new grounds call for but
one sun-dial,and "1908,"with customary progressiveness, saw to it that that one sun-dial should
be erected by them.
Steps were first taken at the end of last year,
when the President of the class, Mr. Purdon
Wright, appointed a committee consisting of
Messrs. Julian Ridgely, Daniel Miller, and
Ralph Williams, to take charge of the matter.
Zealous work by the committee has resulted
in the completion of the dial, which is now on
view.
The dial itself, which is the work of Messrs. Emmert and Ellicott, architects, consists
of a four-foot marble shaft, of beautiful lines, mounted on a concrete base four feet square.
The top is brass, and is set flush with the top of the shaft.
Around the base of the structure is the following legend:
"Erected by the Class of 1908."
The actual erection was done by Wm. A. Gault and Son, at a cost of about $125.
No definite ceremony of unveiling has yet been planned.

It was disagreeable Sunday afternoon in
the down town district. A cold, penetrating
mist filled the air, dampening one's clothes,
and making icy chills run up and down one's
spine. The streets, always thronged with a
busy, hurrying crowd on week days, were
now almost deserted. The few pedestrians
that were about seemed in a hurry to get to
their destinations, where warmth and comfort
undoubtedly awaited them.
With one of these pedestrians, however, this
was not the case. He was slouching along
with a slow, uncertain step that certainly did
not belong to a man who was bound for
warmth and happiness. It was the step of a
man who is discouraged; who has tried the
world and found it harsh and cruel; who despairs of ever attaining that goal of his fellow
pedestrians—warmth, comfort, and happiness.
He slouched along, block after block, and
finally came to a bridge over a stream of dull,
leaden water. He couched into a protected
corner, where a building extended within the
iron railing, and looked down into the filthy,
slow-moving stream. As he looked, the
waters gradually faded away, and in their
place he saw a cozy, little sitting-room with
an open fireplace. The green logs hissed and
crackled and the leaping flames cast a ruddy
glow upon the worn, wrinkled faces of an old
man and woman. At length this vision faded
away, and the ragged crouching man with a
shapeless slouched-hat pulled down over his
face began to mutter, ``I wonder if they are
there now. What would they think if they
could see me now; if they could know what I
have done, and where I have been since I left
them?" Then another vision took shape before him. This time it was not a warm cheerful picture, but a grim, cheerless one. This
time he saw the narrow walls of a prison cell;
the steel walls, the steel floor, the steel ceiling,
the steel door. He heard the endless shuffle
and scraping of feet down the corridor. With
a shudder he drew his hand across his eyes,
crouched lower into the corner, and gave himself up to despair.
"What's the use of trying?" he thought;
"nobody wants to have anything to do with
me. I know I have done wrong, but God
knows how dearly I have paid for it. For

over a month I have tried to get work; but
nobody want me. They all tell me to get
out." With a sob he looked down into the
dark water. As he looked it seemed to become less and less repugnant to him. There
glided peace, perhaps annihilation.
As these thoughts were stealing into his
brain, a heavy hand clutched him by the
shoulder, jerked him up, and pushed him
along. A rough, grumbling voice burst out,
"Come on now, get along there. This is no
place for you." So with slow, uncertain steps
he slouched on up the street.
He pulled his coat-collar up about his bare
neck to protect it from the cold and rain.
Then, with his head bent down, his shoulders
hunched, and his hands thrust deep into his
pockets, he walked square after square.
Finally, he noticed a number of men turning
up into a side street, and, almost without
thinking, he followed them. He saw them
enter the open doors of a large theatre, and
wondered what they could be doing in such a
place on Sunday. Then he noticed a sign—
"Men's Meeting. All welcome."
"Well, here is a place where I can at least
be warm," he thought; so he slouched into
the theatre.
The young usher who met him just within
the threshold seemed doubtful at first whether
to admit him. A person with such a rough,
unshaven face, such bloodshot eyes, such
tousled hair, such dirty clothing might be a
disturbing element in the meeting; so the
usher was about to turn him away. Then he
remembered the words of the evangelist, "Let
every one come, no matter how rough and
wretched he looks. There is always room for
the repentant sinner." So he stepped aside,
and let the outcast enter; then led the way to
a seat in an obscure corner at the side of the
house.
'Well, this is comfort,' the outcast thought,
as he sank back into the chair, and felt a
warm, glowing sensation steal over him. He
did not see the great audience of men, nor the
stage filled with singers; he let his head fall
upon his chest, and gave himself up to comfort. The men sitting near cast annoyed
glances in his direction, when they heard his
heavy breathing; but, when they saw his
rough face and tattered clothing, they did not
disturb him.

SHOULD THE ALUMNI HAVE A
LACROSSE TEAM?

EDITOR NEWS-LETTER :
In answering this question much may be
said pro and con. From an Alumni point of
view it is a very good thing. It gathers together old friends and gives to those of the
Alumni who are cooped up in offices during
the day a chance for exercise. As viewed in
the light of the undergraduate the situation
is entirely different. The Alumni team will
be the better team. It will play better teams
and draw larger crowds than the 'varsity. By
so doing it will diminish the students interest
in the game; and the only athletic organization in which the University has ever excelled
will be obscured.
The Alumni contend that such will not be
the case, and that the Alumni games will not
be played until after the 'varsity season.
Granting this, the same Alumnus says nothing
about one or two of the big teams being reserved for the Alumni. For instance the
University of Toronto has no game with the
'varsity this year, but is reserved for the
Alumni.
If the former football stars of Yale and
Harvard were gathered together into respective Alumni teams, who could estimate the
attendance and enthusiasm of an annual contest. Who could deny that the respective
'varsities would be eclipsed.
The enrollment of a college or university
depends largely upon the advertisement it receives through a medium of its athletic teams.
The average preparatory school boy judges an

institution solely by the success of its athletic
teams. If by any inadvertant means the interest of Hopkins athletics is decreased, I
think the undergraduate department of the
University is to be the sufferer.

It was disagreeable Sunday afternoon in
the down town district. A cold, penetrating
mist filled the air, dampening one's clothes,
and making icy chills run up and down one's
spine. The streets, always thronged with a
busy, hurrying crowd on week days, were
now almost deserted. The few pedestrians
that were about seemed in a hurry to get to
their destinations, where warmth and comfort
undoubtedly awaited them.
With one of these pedestrians, however, this
was not the case. He was slouching along
with a slow, uncertain step that certainly did
not belong to a man who was bound for
warmth and happiness. It was the step of a
man who is discouraged; who has tried the
world and found it harsh and cruel; who despairs of ever attaining that goal of his fellow
pedestrians—warmth, comfort, and happiness.
He slouched along, block after block, and
finally came to a bridge over a stream of dull,
leaden water. He couched into a protected
corner, where a building extended within the
iron railing, and looked down into the filthy,
slow-moving stream. As he looked, the
waters gradually faded away, and in their
place he saw a cozy, little sitting-room with
an open fireplace. The green logs hissed and
crackled and the leaping flames cast a ruddy
glow upon the worn, wrinkled faces of an old
man and woman. At length this vision faded
away, and the ragged crouching man with a
shapeless slouched-hat pulled down over his
face began to mutter, ``I wonder if they are
there now. What would they think if they
could see me now; if they could know what I
have done, and where I have been since I left
them?" Then another vision took shape before him. This time it was not a warm cheerful picture, but a grim, cheerless one. This
time he saw the narrow walls of a prison cell;
the steel walls, the steel floor, the steel ceiling,
the steel door. He heard the endless shuffle
and scraping of feet down the corridor. With
a shudder he drew his hand across his eyes,
crouched lower into the corner, and gave himself up to despair.
"What's the use of trying?" he thought;
"nobody wants to have anything to do with
me. I know I have done wrong, but God
knows how dearly I have paid for it. For

over a month I have tried to get work; but
nobody want me. They all tell me to get
out." With a sob he looked down into the
dark water. As he looked it seemed to become less and less repugnant to him. There
glided peace, perhaps annihilation.
As these thoughts were stealing into his
brain, a heavy hand clutched him by the
shoulder, jerked him up, and pushed him
along. A rough, grumbling voice burst out,
"Come on now, get along there. This is no
place for you." So with slow, uncertain steps
he slouched on up the street.
He pulled his coat-collar up about his bare
neck to protect it from the cold and rain.
Then, with his head bent down, his shoulders
hunched, and his hands thrust deep into his
pockets, he walked square after square.
Finally, he noticed a number of men turning
up into a side street, and, almost without
thinking, he followed them. He saw them
enter the open doors of a large theatre, and
wondered what they could be doing in such a
place on Sunday. Then he noticed a sign—
"Men's Meeting. All welcome."
"Well, here is a place where I can at least
be warm," he thought; so he slouched into
the theatre.
The young usher who met him just within
the threshold seemed doubtful at first whether
to admit him. A person with such a rough,
unshaven face, such bloodshot eyes, such
tousled hair, such dirty clothing might be a
disturbing element in the meeting; so the
usher was about to turn him away. Then he
remembered the words of the evangelist, "Let
every one come, no matter how rough and
wretched he looks. There is always room for
the repentant sinner." So he stepped aside,
and let the outcast enter; then led the way to
a seat in an obscure corner at the side of the
house.
'Well, this is comfort,' the outcast thought,
as he sank back into the chair, and felt a
warm, glowing sensation steal over him. He
did not see the great audience of men, nor the
stage filled with singers; he let his head fall
upon his chest, and gave himself up to comfort. The men sitting near cast annoyed
glances in his direction, when they heard his
heavy breathing; but, when they saw his
rough face and tattered clothing, they did not
disturb him.

EDITOR NEWS-LETTER :
In answering this question much may be
said pro and con. From an Alumni point of
view it is a very good thing. It gathers together old friends and gives to those of the
Alumni who are cooped up in offices during
the day a chance for exercise. As viewed in
the light of the undergraduate the situation
is entirely different. The Alumni team will
be the better team. It will play better teams
and draw larger crowds than the 'varsity. By
so doing it will diminish the students interest
in the game; and the only athletic organization in which the University has ever excelled
will be obscured.
The Alumni contend that such will not be
the case, and that the Alumni games will not
be played until after the 'varsity season.
Granting this, the same Alumnus says nothing
about one or two of the big teams being reserved for the Alumni. For instance the
University of Toronto has no game with the
'varsity this year, but is reserved for the
Alumni.
If the former football stars of Yale and
Harvard were gathered together into respective Alumni teams, who could estimate the
attendance and enthusiasm of an annual contest. Who could deny that the respective
'varsities would be eclipsed.
The enrollment of a college or university
depends largely upon the advertisement it receives through a medium of its athletic teams.
The average preparatory school boy judges an

institution solely by the success of its athletic
teams. If by any inadvertant means the interest of Hopkins athletics is decreased, I
think the undergraduate department of the
University is to be the sufferer.

THE MERRY BACHELORS.
Outside the tavern drifts the snow,
But what care we for weather?
What if the sharp winds keenly blow?
We'll spend the night together.
Icicles fringe the barren trees,
The brook is frozen over.
We care not if the whole world freeze,—
We're safe and under cover.
So gather 'round the glowing grate.
The bitter night is falling.
Adventures rare will we relate,
Old friends and scenes recalling.
So pile the heavy night-log high,
And keep the bright sparks whirling
Up the old chimney soaring high,
